title: andrew neil sues jennifer arcuri claims linked epstein
story: Andrew Neil is suing Jennifer Arcuri over claims he was linked to Jeffrey Epstein, saying he never met the paedophile and that it was Ghislaine Maxwell who put him in the businessman’s “black book”.On Tuesday, Mr Neil also threatened to take legal action against any Twitter users who reposted and endorsed the “vile and untrue accusations” on the social media site.The row erupted after Ms Arcuri, an entrepreneur who has previously claimed to have had a romantic relationship with Boris Johnson, tweeted images of Mr Neil’s address in Mr Epstein’s “black book” of contacts along with the suggestion the veteran journalist knew the disgraced financier.The tweet was deleted after Mr Neil said he was instructing his solicitors to take action over “this clear libel and defamation”.He also warned other Twitter users retweeting the accusation, saying: “I’m taking this action not just to hold Arcuri, who I’ve never met and have no interest in, to account but, more importantly, to establish that the twitterati can’t just promulgate evil lies without consequences. “If you think anonymity will protect you, you’re in for a big surprise.”Ms Arcuri later denied on Twitter she had deleted the tweet in response to the threat of litigation, saying it was instead because the image was already “all over the internet” and “all public domain”.Following the accusation, Mr Neil tweeted he had appeared in the black book as he had met Ghislaine Maxwell three times in New York in the mid-Nineties.He added: “I never met Epstein or frequented any of his properties. Think carefully before you sayimply anything else.”The  understands the meetings between Mr Neil and Maxwell were brief social encounters, in which Epstein was never mentioned, and that the pair had not spoken in the intervening 26 years.Sources close to the broadcaster said Mr Neil is now seeking “substantial damages” from Ms Arcuri, even if she offered an apology, and intended to donate any proceeds from the action to a charity supporting victims of child abuse.More from NewsChristmas work from home order being drawn up by GovernmentGhislaine Maxwell trial: Accuser Carolyn &#39was paid $300 to massage Jeffrey Epstein age 14&#39One in 10 who worked from home experienced domestic abuse, poll findsBureaucratic Britain has become addicted to permanent failureTop Foreign Office civil servant who was on holiday during fall of Kabul ‘should resign’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: cheugy one mispronounced words year
story: Cheugy, a term used to mock unfashionable millennials, has been voted as one of the most mispronounced words of the year.The word, meaning no longer regarded as cool or fashionable, is believed to be coined in 2013 and is used to target millennials, the oldest of whom are reaching 40, and aesthetics which include slogans such as “Live Laugh Love” and “Wine-O-Clock”.It was last month beaten to the top spot of Collins dictionary’s word of the year by NFT (non-fungible token), a unique and non-interchangeable unit of data.The word is pronounced “CHOO-gee”, but many people have mispronounced it as “Chuggy”, “CHO-jee” or “SHOE-gee”.The research, conducted by language-learning app, Babbel, and the British Institute of Verbatim Reporters is in its sixth year and has investigated which words have tripped up members of the public and news anchors alike.Other words which have made it on to the list included the surname of Gina Coladangelo, Matt Hancock’s former aide and lover, as well as the cryptocurrency Dogecoin and the pop singer Billie Eilish.Todd Ehresmann, a senior linguist at Babbel, said: “It’s always interesting for us to take our annual look at the terms that have been most mispronounced, as they are usually new vernacular or words that are borrowed from, or have origins in, another language.“As they come into everyday parlance, it’s great to see people at least having a stab at saying them correctly, because having the confidence to speak new words and phrases is one of the most important aspects when learning a language.”More from title: dont rush ban conversion therapy
story: There is a public consultation closing on Friday that, should some of its recommendations be poorly implemented in law, would have damaging consequences for children.It could create a situation whereby doctors, counsellors and therapists would be deterred from exploring with a child any feelings of gender dysphoria – discomfort with their sexed body – for fear that they will be accused of trying to “change” the child’s identity and potentially being dragged through the criminal justice system.It could require parents to simply affirm a child’s assertion that they are “trans” since not to do so would be interpreted as “conversion therapy”. It could make it illegal to try to help a son or daughter accept their body as it is rather than pursue a pathway to puberty blockers, cross-sex hormones, and surgery. It risks erasing the possibility for children to be different, to not conform to stereotypes and to work through their emotional turmoil. Instead of helping children deal with the fact that sometimes things can’t be easily resolved – that it’s possible to be a feminine boy or a masculine girl – the law could increase the pressure towards a more rigid choice.It ignores the fact that most children presenting with gender dysphoria find it resolves as adults. And it may shut down exploration of why there has been such a huge rise in the number of children who have concerns about their gender, why two thirds are girls, the prevalence of autism, or why gender dysphoria is particularly common among children who go on to become gay or lesbian adults.The proposed law follows a campaign by Stonewall to extend a ban on conversion therapy for sexual orientation, on which there is near universal agreement, to cover talking therapies that intend to change a person from being transgender. That sounds simple, but it conceals huge complexity, particularly as it relates to children.It requires the Government to define what it means to be a transgender child, as opposed to a child suffering from gender dysphoria. As there is no objective test, it moves the Government into accepting the principle of self-identification. Is the bar the assertion by a girl that she is a boy, or vice-versa? How long must they hold this belief? At what stage does legitimate therapy or conversations that seek to explore what might underpin a child’s assertion that they are in the wrong body become vulnerable to accusations that the intent was to change a transgender child?The legal defence is that there must be an “intention” to change the person to or from being transgender, and that the Government wishes to preserve talking therapies that support those who are “questioning their LGBT status”. But how do you define in law “questioning”? Is it compatible with a firm assertion “I am trans”? How does the Government take into account the risk of a chilling effect, where legitimate clinicians withdraw from providing support because they do not want to risk being dragged through the courts? What of freedom of belief and speech? Many people would argue passionately you cannot be born in the wrong body. They are currently free to express what they believe to be the case. But if gender identity is “how you feel”, and your feelings are altered by hearing others’ arguments, have you been subjected to conversion therapy?These issues are so complex and sensitive, you’d be forgiven for thinking the Government will approach the drafting of the legislation with care. That it would wait for the NHS’s Cass Review, which will set out a definition of good care for children with gender dysphoria. Yet the opposite is true. The Government has promised a draft bill for spring 2022. Only six weeks have been allowed for the consultation, two months to analyse the responses and make policy decisions, and a handful of weeks to draft the Bill.As director of legislative affairs for two prime ministers, I know there are times you have to work fast to get a bill on to the statute books, but there’s no deadline for this legislation. Nor does taking a little more time leave anyone vulnerable: the vast majority of activities considered conversion therapy are already prohibited. Those rushing to show progress for the “Safe to be Me” conference need to recognise that it will last only a few days, but the Act will be on the statute book for years and the Bill will take months to progress through Parliament.Lobby groups will also seek to amend the Bill to achieve other objectives. These could include lowering the age for cross-sex hormones and making puberty blocking drugs more readily available. If the Bill offers a definition of being transgender, alternative, more expansive, definitions could be proposed, potentially with the intention of amending the Equality Act, or the Gender Recognition Act.The Government must slow down. At the very least arrange pre-legislative scrutiny in a Joint Committee. It can go through the draft Bill, seek further evidence, test the policy, and make suggestions. It will help build consensus.Nikki da Costa is a former head of legislative affairs at No 10 Downing StreetMore from NewsChristmas work from home order being drawn up by GovernmentGhislaine Maxwell trial: Accuser Carolyn &#39was paid $300 to massage Jeffrey Epstein age 14&#39One in 10 who worked from home experienced domestic abuse, poll findsBureaucratic Britain has become addicted to permanent failureTop Foreign Office civil servant who was on holiday during fall of Kabul ‘should resign’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: hong kong visa scheme immigration policy done right
story: In one swift legislative move at the start of this year, Britain opened up a pathway to citizenship for 5.4 million people. We should not underrate the generosity of this country’s decision to stand by its obligations to Hong Kong. Yet you may have scarcely heard about it since, and that is because one of the largest changes to British immigration law in recent history has been so smooth that it is almost underwhelming.Recent history tells us that it is notoriously hard to predict the number of people who plan to take up newfound rights to migrate. Yet the Government’s predictions on Hong Kongers have proven reliable. Whitehall’s central estimate was that 120,000 would apply for the British National Overseas (BNO) visa in the first year. By the end of September, 89,200 had applied.On the prediction of a £2.6 billion fiscal benefit too, the Government seems to have gotten hold of the right end of the stick. The University of Oxford's first large-scale survey of BNOs showed that those who have considered moving to the UK are younger, have higher educational qualifications, a higher employment rate and are generally wealthier than those who plan to stay in Hong Kong. They are dissatisfied with Hong Kong’s political environment and attracted by the prospect of freedom and the rule of law. Many have been impressed by what we have offered and galvanised by the speed of processing by the Home Office. Around 70,000 have already seen their applications approved.With little fanfare, they have settled across the United Kingdom. One group has set up bed and breakfasts in Blackpool many families have moved to Birmingham and the outskirts of Manchester others to York. Local community organisations, as well as fellow Hong Kongers, have been effective at providing support, language lessons and advice to help new arrivals settle in.There are still a few things to be ironed out. A large number of 18-25 year old Hong Kongers — which is the age group most likely to be targeted by the crackdown — are ineligible for the scheme, often when they are dependent on parents with BNO status who may not be ready to move. Some of these young people are stuck in the asylum process, despite having a case as clear as day, and the most eagerness to get on and work. That is why a cross-party group of MPs has tabled an amendment to the Nationality and Borders Bill, which is being debated this week, to extend the scheme to anyone who has one parent with BNO status. There is also the question of how we can protect them from harassment, for many remain nervous about being targeted by supporters of the Chinese Communist Party despite being 5,000 miles away from Beijing. In Hong Kong, CCP-friendly newspapers and politicians have stoked disinformation about citizenship and intolerance in Britain. The police must take these threats seriously. Still, the broad picture remains very positive. Britain is showing the world that it can still provide a safe haven for those who have been persecuted abroad. We have lived up both to our obligations to Hong Kong and to our history of opening our arms to refugees. It is something of which we can be incredibly proud.More from NewsChristmas work from home order being drawn up by GovernmentGhislaine Maxwell trial: Accuser Carolyn &#39was paid $300 to massage Jeffrey Epstein age 14&#39One in 10 who worked from home experienced domestic abuse, poll findsBureaucratic Britain has become addicted to permanent failureTop Foreign Office civil servant who was on holiday during fall of Kabul ‘should resign’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: phileas fogg represented best victorian derring do
story: Has David Tennant really got the measure of Phileas Fogg? Tennant, who plays Jules Verne’s globetrotting hero in the new BBC dramatisation of Around the World in 80 Days, describes Fogg as “a particularly stuffy Englishman” who “represents everything that’s alarming and peculiar about that old sense of British Empire”.To start with, I’d question the stuffiness. I concede that Verne’s 1872 novel begins with Fogg, a man who lives by rigid routines, dismissing his manservant because he “has brought him shaving-water at 84 degrees Fahrenheit instead of 86”. But Verne describes his behaviour as “eccentric”. Fogg’s extreme standards stem from his unusually precise, mathematical way of thinking – the very opposite of stuffiness, which is all about following convention.Besides, Fogg soon abandons his comfortable routines once he embarks on his journey. What’s stuffy about dropping everything and circumnavigating the globe for a bet?Neither is Fogg a tub-thumping reactionary. He is, famously, a member of the Reform Club – perhaps not a guarantee of un-stuffiness nowadays, but in the Victorian era a sign that you were committed to radical politics. One doesn’t have the sense from Tennant’s remarks that he realises Fogg belonged to a club that banned copies of the Daily  from its premises.But Fogg is no racist. Indeed, he ends the novel engaged to Aouda, the Indian woman he rescues from being burned alive in a suttee ritual.In the end, a chap who travels around sorting out other people’s problems is an eternally appealing figure in the adventure genre – as former Doctor Who David Tennant would no doubt concede.Fogg belongs in the pantheon of the great fictional travellers who flourished during the second half of the 19th century – a golden age for adventure writing. Figures such as the heroes in G A Henty’s stories for boys, or Allan Quatermain in the novels of H Rider Haggard, were plucky and venturesome – they cast themselves into unknown and probably hostile territory to challenge themselves, not for gain.The “civilising” of Africans is anathema to men like Quatermain, who envies them for knowing “nothing about steam, electricity, or gunpowder, and mercifully for themselves nothing about printing and the penny post” he also rails against the enslavement and exploitation of Africans by white men.Robert Louis Stevenson, defending the adventure novel from attacks by Henry James and others, observed in 1884 that the genre “appeals to certain almost sensual and quite illogical tendencies in man” – that is, the counterintuitive desire, in an increasingly civilised world, to experience a little danger and discomfort.If the Tennant series focuses on Fogg as a hidebound imperialist lackey instead of trying to capture that spirit of romantic freedom, it will be a sorry thing.More from NewsChristmas work from home order being drawn up by GovernmentGhislaine Maxwell trial: Accuser Carolyn &#39was paid $300 to massage Jeffrey Epstein age 14&#39One in 10 who worked from home experienced domestic abuse, poll findsBureaucratic Britain has become addicted to permanent failureTop Foreign Office civil servant who was on holiday during fall of Kabul ‘should resign’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: progressive alliance would prolong lefts delusions
story: It’s an old joke so forgive me if you’ve heard it before: a Labour activist is walking along a clifftop path when he sees two people – a Conservative and a Liberal Democrat – clinging to the edge for dear life. So which one does he kick off first? The Tory, of course. Business before pleasure.Those of a less political nature will scratch their heads in bewilderment at the age-old rivalry – or perhaps hatred is a more appropriate word – between the two Left-of-centre opposition parties. After all, they want many of the same things: fairer taxes, fairer industrial policy, fairer foreign policy, fairer housing, a fairer economy, a fairer voting system…Ok, you can scratch that last one, which has long been a bone of contention between Labour and the Lib Dems. But the one thing they do have in common is a desire to rid the country of this Conservative government. The problem then arises: and replace it with what?A week on Thursday voters in North Shropshire will go to the polls to elect a replacement for disgraced former cabinet minister Owen Paterson. It’s one of those classic battlegrounds at which the Lib Dems have historically gained advantage by being the less hated of the three main options. Following the traditional post-election period in which Left-leaning columnists call for a “progressive alliance” to remove the Conservatives from office, the Lib Dems have intensified their demands that Labour voters in North Shropshire switch their support to them. This is a bold strategy for a party that last finished as runner-up in the seat in 2010 and who have been soundly beaten by Labour in every general election there since. But perception is everything and Ed Davey’s party will have been bolstered in its efforts to seize the progressive standard by a peculiar editorial in this morning’s  suggesting the Lib Dems are indeed more likely to win than Labour. In by-elections, parties’ internal polling is every bit as valuable as Monopoly £500 notes, but it’s worth noting that both Labour and the Lib Dems have produced “surveys” of voters – presumably in radically different parts of the constituency – showing them to be within reach of victory. Both opposition parties desperately need the morale boost victory would bestow. But why is such a progressive alliance so difficult to attain?The elephant in the room is, of course, the 2010-2015 coalition government. Davey himself, it will never be forgotten, served as a cabinet minister in David Cameron’s administration the same one that implemented austerity, cut services and trebled university tuition fees – a reform the Lib Dems strenuously opposed during the general election campaign, then enthusiastically voted for after it had ended. In time the Lib Dems may well shake off their reputation as the Conservatives’ little helpers, but that task is all the greater when the coalition’s former climate change secretary is leading it.The fact is that Lib Dems provide the main opposition to Labour in hundreds of local areas across the country. Labour MPs in particular are familiar with the party’s cynical (but effective) campaign tactics that have so frequently left Labour in its wake. And although the Parliamentary Labour Party is now greatly depleted, there are enough older MPs still around who recall the vehemence with which the Lib Dems opposed many parts of the last Labour government’s agenda, right up until the point where they went into partnership with the Conservatives.Talk of an alliance, therefore, is fanciful. And proponents are demanding it at exactly the wrong time, when Labour has started to make serious, though modest, progress in the polls. The time to make the case for an anti-Conservative alliance is when the government is popular and is looking unbeatable. Now, when Keir Starmer looks like he might actually make the next election competitive, is not that time.From Labour’s point of view, stepping aside for the sake of the Lib Dems, even if such an arrangement falls short of a formal electoral pact, holds very few benefits. If North Shropshire were to fall to either of the opposition parties, it would not be a huge surprise, given the circumstances in which it was called. When Government ministers and backbench MPs appear on the following morning’s radio and TV bulletins to explain why the party lost, no one is going to accuse them of spin. Indeed, a Tory victory – still an outside possibility – could accurately be depicted as an astonishing victory, so poor were the party’s prospects at the start of the campaign.So what would Labour gain from a Lib Dem win? Nothing whatever, except a short-lived blip in the polls for a rival party.The challenge facing Labour is the same as it has always been, whatever optimistic scenarios of “progressive alliances” dominate the fantasies of anti-Conservative commentators: how to win an election in its own right. Yearning after a shortcut to victory, either through an electoral alliance or via electoral reform, is simply a deflection strategy that allows the Left to focus on tactics rather than to make the hard choices about how to change enough so that they attract the support of previously reluctant voters.Labour needs to go all out for victory in North Shropshire and everywhere else, treating every other party – whether the Lib Dems, the Greens or the Scottish nationalists – as as much of an opponent as the Conservatives themselves. Because if they ever get back into government, they will find – as they did between 1997 and 2010 – that so-called parties of the Left will be as supportive of a Labour government as the Conservatives will be.More from NewsChristmas work from home order being drawn up by GovernmentGhislaine Maxwell trial: Accuser Carolyn &#39was paid $300 to massage Jeffrey Epstein age 14&#39One in 10 who worked from home experienced domestic abuse, poll findsBureaucratic Britain has become addicted to permanent failureTop Foreign Office civil servant who was on holiday during fall of Kabul ‘should resign’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: stonehenge sea unveiled british museum
story: A “Stonehenge of the sea” is to be displayed at the British Museum, as part of the first major exhibition on its more familiar contemporary.Seahenge, as it is known, consists of an oak tree’s upturned roots surrounded by 54 wooden posts that would have been nearly 10 feet tall, arranged in a 21-foot diameter circle.The exact purpose of the henge and its flipped over stump is unclear, although there has been some speculation that it may have been used to lay bodies on, with scavenger birds able to feast on the flesh of the dead.“If Stonehenge is one of the world’s most remarkable surviving ancient stone circles, then Seahenge is the equivalent in timber,” said Dr Jennifer Wexler, the project curator of the exhibition, adding that it is “still relatively unknown”.The henge is also known as Holme I, after the village of Holme-next-the-Sea where it was discovered by an amateur archaeologist in 1998.Having initially found a Bronze Age axe head, John Lorimer made repeated visits to the beach, eventually uncovering the tree stump and calling in professional archaeologists from Norfolk Castle Museum.Amid controversy and protests, in particular from self-styled modern-day druids with didgeridoos, the full henge was excavated and removed from its original site.Exposure to oxygen and saltwater risked rapid deterioration of the wood, which had spent four millennia encased in peat.It was transferred to the Mary Rose Trust in Portsmouth, which specialises in preserving waterlogged timber, and was stabilised before going on display at the Lynn Museum in King’s Lynn.The henge has never gone on loan before, with Dr Neil Wilkin, the curator of the exhibition, saying that the museum was surprised their request was accepted.Much of the 4,000-year-old construction’s origins and purpose are still unknown to researchers, but they are certain that it held spiritual significance, with the doorway to the circle aligned with the midsummer sun.Visitors to the exhibition, which runs from February 17 to July 17, will be able to pass through that doorway themselves.Seahenge's more well-known stone equivalent sits on Salisbury Plain in Wiltshire and has long fascinated experts and the public alike. It is believed to have been built over several centuries, somewhere around 3,000 BC to 2,000 BC.While some have speculated that Stonehenge may have been used for healing or for studying the cosmos, a more widely held theory is that it formed the culmination of a funerary procession from the River Avon.Stonehenge and Seahenge are two of just 120 known henges in Britain, while there are over 1,000 stone circles which are more likely to survive the country's harsh weather conditions than their timber counterparts.The Seahenge timbers are among over 430 objects brought together from across the UK and Europe for what will be the British Museum’s largest exhibition for several years.The curators hope to dispel the idea that the creators of Stonehenge existed in an isolated and primitive society. The loans and items from the museum’s own collection come from across Europe, including France, Switzerland, Germany and Portugal and display the rich cultural world and networks of exchange within which neolithic Britons existed.The majority have not been seen in the UK before.“We think of Stonehenge as an English and a British monument. But actually, when you start to look at it, the tentacles of the root systems reach out across Britain and across Europe,” said Dr Wilkin. Also among the items displayed will be two remarkable cone-shaped gold hats, resembling those of a wizard, and the full Bush Barrow Hoard from the Wiltshire Museum which includes the finest example of Bronze Age gold craftsmanship ever found in Britain.More from NewsChristmas work from home order being drawn up by GovernmentGhislaine Maxwell trial: Accuser Carolyn &#39was paid $300 to massage Jeffrey Epstein age 14&#39One in 10 who worked from home experienced domestic abuse, poll findsBureaucratic Britain has become addicted to permanent failureTop Foreign Office civil servant who was on holiday during fall of Kabul ‘should resign’More from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

story: Exclusive: David Cameron refuses to sayhed attend Grenfell inquiry after ridiculing rulesEXCLUSIVE: Returning red-faced from a morning spot of tennis at a local club, Mr Cameron repeatedly said “morning” to the Mirror but would not answer our questions on the inquiryFormer PM David Cameron leaves his Notting Hill home Image: TIM ANDERSONByMatthew Young:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsDavid Cameron this morning refused to say whether he would attend the Grenfell Tower inquirycalled upon. It came after Michael Mansfield QC, a lawyer for the bereaved and survivors of the tragedy, yesterday said the former Tory PM should be called to answer questions at the probe into the June  fire, which killed  people. Mr Cameron said in  how he wanted to “scrap health and safety rules that put people off”, the inquiry heard on Monday. The following year he disparaged the “shadow” of health and safety, saying: “Britannia didn’t rule the waves with armbands on.” Mr Mansfield said Cameron ridiculed health and safety rules “relegating citizens…to effectively a bonfire”. Mr Cameron was being referred to by lawyers as they described more than  years of cover ups of the extent of the cladding crisis that led to the blaze. But the former PM, , refused to say this morning whether he would attend the inquirycalled upon. Returning red-faced from a morning spot of tennis at a local club, Mr Cameron repeatedly said “morning” to the Mirror but would not answer our questions on the inquiry or whether he would attend. He entered his plush Notting Hill home - which lies just one mile from Grenfell Tower - and slammed the door shut. In response to the claims made in the inquiry Mr Cameron’s spokesman said he was for “a sensible approach to health and safety [rules] to ensure they protected people and were applied where needed rather than unnecessarily overwhelm businesses with red tape”.Do you think David Cameron should face the inquiry  Join the debate in the comments below The previously inquiry heard how the government acknowledged that a rule against introducing new regulations for the building industry in the s put it in breach of its duty to protect the right to le. The hearing heard the government suppressed information about the combustibility of cladding used on Lakanal House after a fire killed six people in  in Camberwell, south east London. It noted the need to “avoid giving the impression that we believe all buildings of this constructioninherently unsafe”. The investigation into this fire was shut down by officials in a “grotesque abdication of responsibility” which “raises the spectre of a deliberate cover up”, the inqury was told.  After Lakanal, despite the government outwardly promising to implement the coroner’s recommendation to encourage the use of sprinklers, civil servants wrote that it was simply acting “to be able to say that DCLG is taking action”. A senior civil servant warned in May  – just a month before the Grenfell Tower fire – that “we or ministers are increasingly vulnerable to some or all of these risks becoming material andbeing held to account for being inactive”. The inquiry continues today. title: labour veteran harriet harman step
story: Labour veteran Harriet Harman to step down as MP at next election after  yearsThe Camberwell and Peckham MP told constituents she would not stand again at the next electionVeteran Labour MP Harriet Harman has announced she will step down at the next election Image: Daily MirrorByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsLong-standing Labour MP Harriet Harman has announced she will stand down at the next election. The former minister informed her constituents that she intended to step back after nearly  years in Parliament. Ms Harman, , is known as the aposMother of the Houseapos as Britainaposs longest serving female MP, first joining the Commons as MP for Camberwell and Peckham in .In an email to constituents, she said: I feel I can leave the House of Commons now confident that Labour is gaining strength under the leadership of Keir Starmer and the new team he has appointed.It has been an overwhelming honour to be Member of Parliament representing and working for the people of Camberwell and Peckham for nearly  years.  Ms Harman has served as acting Labour leader and deputy leader, as well as holding several Government roles over her long career. A veteran feminist campaigner, she held the post of Secretary of State for Social Security and became the first Minister for Women. She also served as a Justice Minister, Leader of the House of Commons and Solicitor General. Ms Harman said: I entered the Commons as one of only  Labour women MPs in a parliament that was % men. Now there are  Labour women and across all parties women MPs are a “critical mass.” But there remains much more to be done till women genuinely share political power with men on equal terms and until women in this country are equal. I will leave the House of Commons with my feminism, my belief in Labour and my enthusiasm for politics undimmed. She added: When I was elected in  I promised the voters I would serve as their MP with dedication and energy till the next election and I will do that, remaining active and diligent both locally and in the Commons. Labour leader Keir Starmer led tributes to Ms Harman, who he said had paved the way for future generations. Harriet, your commitment to Labour and Camberwell and Peckham for almost  years is phenomenal, he said. A champion for women and social justice - youaposve paved the way for future generations. Itaposs been a privilege to work with you, I look forward to continuing to do so for a while yet.  Ed Miliband, who led the party with Ms Harman as his deputy between  and , described her as a feminist, fighter, conviction politician. Harriet taught me so much as my first political boss and was a brilliant deputy, he said. She has achieved so much and will be sorely missed from the House of Commons. Shadow culture secretary Lucy Powell described her a trail-blazer for women. Sheaposs incredibly effective, very loyal, fierce, formidable and very kind. She taught me so much, she said. And London Mayor Sadiq Khan said: My friend Harriet has given the people of Camberwell and Peckham, the Labour movement and our country a letime of outstanding service. This news is a loss to many. On behalf of our city, thank you! We wish you the best, Harriet. Her announcement comes after veteran Labour MPs Margaret Hodge and Barry Sheerman also declared they would step down at the next election.Britain is due to go to the polls in May  - but there has been speculation that Boris Johnson could call an early election in .Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Harriet HarmanLabour Party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: matt hancock calls dyslexia screening
story: Matt Hancock calls for dyslexia screening at primary schools to drive down crimeThe former Health Secretary called on MPs to support his Dyslexia Screening Bill to break the link of dyslexia and prison. He recalled feeling frustrated as a teen because of his undiagnosed dyslexia. Image: PAByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Dec | commentsMatt Hancock has called for the introduction of dyslexia screening at primary schools to break the link with the learning dficulty and crime. The ex-Health Secretary told MPs  per cent of young people slip through the cracks and head into the world of work without being diagnosed. There are correlations between dyslexia and unemployment, drug usage, school exclusions and homelessness, he told MPs and highlighted more than half of the prison population are dyslexic. These are the knock on effects of undiagnosed dyslexia, and we have the tools to solve this injustice. Introducing his Dyslexia Screening Bill, he said Iaposm proud to be dyslexic, but admitted it wasnapost always that way.  As a teenager, I didnapost know I was dyslexic. I spent my school years focusing on maths and science subjects, always trying to avoid anything that needed more than a few sentences. He recalled the light bulb moment he experienced once he was told of his learning dficulty. Mr Hancock was not diagnosed with dyslexia until he went to Oxford University aged . “I was one of the lucky ones who was caught. There are too many children who are not caught early enough. It is a quiet scandal that an estimated four-in-five dyslexic children leave school with their dyslexia unidentied, he told MPs. He told the Commons it is a quiet scandal that some young people have their potential unrealised and often their confidence undermined because they are unaware of their condition. Mr Hancock told MPs specialist teachers who had training to spot the learning dficulty, alongside cheap and essay computer-based screening tools” would help many young people. Mr Hancock’s Dyslexia Screening Bill received support from a cross-party group of MPs, but is unlikely to become law without Government backing. The former Health Secretary who was a key face during the Covid pandemic quit his Cabinet position after CCTV footage surfaced, showing him breaching social distancing rules, kissing his aide in his Whitehall office. He told ITVaposs Peston show he is in no rush to get back into Government and is enjoying sitting on the back benches.“Itaposs a very important job and I think contributions from people who’ve been there in the heat of the battle [like] Mark [Harper] as chief whip... or Theresa May – the contributions she makes as former prime minister – andI can make that sort of contribution in the House of Commons then I’ll enjoy doing it.Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CabinetHouse of CommonsSchoolsPoliticsHomelessness" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: No  has Noel idea and it may lead to an unhappy New Year - Voice of the MirrorContinued contradictory messages from a rule-breaking Prime Minister on both parties and socialising is heightening concern as the coronavirus spreads, including an Omicron iant worrying virologistsBoris Johnson is making a big gamble with his Christmas plans Image: PAopinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsIf we enjoy a merry Christmas, we may be faced with an unhappy New Year – a warning that none of us wanted to hear. The words yesterday from Cambridge University statistician Prof Sir David Spiegelhalter rang alarm bells about the potential impact of Christmas socialising. Continued contradictory messages from a rule-breaking Prime Minister on both parties and socialising is heightening concern as the coronavirus spreads, including an Omicron iant worrying virologists. And when vaccines are the main line of Britain’s defence in this pandemic, Boris Johnson’s failure to mobilise a national jabbing programme to match the huge effort earlier this year is a lethal and expensive blunder. Statistics released by Labour leader Keir Starmer, showing , doses in a recent -hour period were less than half the , in a day at the peak last March, damn a frequently complacent and dithering No . More suffering The killing of Arthur Labinjo-Hughes demands a national review to protect other children from evil crimes – but regrettably there is no certainty other little innocents will not lose their lives. We heard that from Government ministers after Victoria Climbie, Baby P – Peter Connolly, Daniel Pelka and now Arthur that lessons must be learned and perhaps some were. Yet children continue to die after facing the most horric and unthinkable cruelty. Increasing already y prison sentences may assuage public anger and deliver what many would applaud as tougher justice. What does not exist is evidence the prospect of extra years in prison would deter depraved adults. news politics no--staff-filmed-joking-"Staff joke about Downing Street Christmas party during lockdownByRachel WearmouthSenior Political Correspondent:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsSenior Downing Street staff cracked jokes about a rule-breaking Christmas party at No  just four days after it was alleged to have taken place, a bombshell leaked recording reveals. Officials can be heard laughing about cheese and wine as Boris Johnsonaposs former spokeswoman Allegra Stratton cracked jokes about a business meeting in which there was “definitely no social distancing.” The recording, passed to ITV News, is of a rehearsal on December  for planned daily TV media briefings, which Ms Stratton was supposed to be the face of but the Prime Minister later scrapped. Staff in the  Downing Street press room can be heard pretending to ask questions about a party. Boris Johnson has faced calls to resignreports of the party are true, while Labour leader Keir Starmer said he must come clean about it. Ed Oldfield, adviser to the PM, said: “I’ve just seen reports on Twitter that there was a Downing Street Christmas party on Friday night, do you recognise those reports ”  “I went home”, replies Ms Stratton, who appears to crease up laughing before telling colleagues hold on. Following a long pause, Mr Oldfield goes on: “Would the prime minister condone having a Christmas party ” Ms Stratton laughs and says “what’s the answer  before her colleagues step in to help her compose an answer. “It wasn’t a party, it was cheese and wine”, offers one. “Is cheese and wine alright ” Ms Stratton asks, before adding, again laughing “it was a business meeting”. She then warns those present “this is recorded” and says “this fictional party was a business meeting and it was not socially distanced.”  Downing Street has denied there was a party and, when asked himself, the Prime Minister said he had been assured guidance was followed. It comes after the Daily Mirror revealed bombshell allegations that revellers at an unofficial No Christmas bash on December  allegedly enjoyed food, drinks and games which went on well past midnight. Fresh allegations in the Times also revealed that officials organised a apossecret Santaapos and sent out invites, suggesting the event was planned. Millions of people were living under strict Covid rules at the time - with London under Tier  restrictions.  The following day Mr Johnson announced that Christmas plans had to be drastically scaled back. Keir Starmer, leader of the Labour Party, said: “People across the country followed the rules even when that meant being separated from their families, locked down and - tragically for many - unable to say goodbye to their loved ones. “They had a right to expect that the government was doing the same. To lie and to laugh about those lies is shameful. “The Prime Minister now needs to come clean, and apologise. It cannot be one rule for the Conservatives and another for everyone .”  The SNPaposs Westminster leader Ian Blackford said: This video is damning and leaves the Prime Minister with a lot to answer for. When every inidual up and down the country was told to stay at home in order to protect the NHS, the Tories were instead having a Christmas party which, as a senior staff member has now confirmed, was aposnot socially distancedapos.If this is true, then the Prime Ministeraposs position is untenable and he must remove himself from office immediately. Ms Stratton remains the Prime Ministeraposs spokeswoman on Cop and had previously worked as head of communications for Chancellor Rishi Sunak.The Chancellor was pressed on whether he or any of his special advisers had attended the Christmas parties in Downing Street last year.He told MPs: No, I did not attend any parties.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Boris JohnsonPoliticsChristmas party" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: not vaccinating primary school kids
story: Not vaccinating primary school kids is scandalous negligence - parents deserve choicePrimary school age children in the US, Australia and some European countries are getting jabbed, so why not here  Some parents won’t want their kids to be vaccinated but I do, desperately. So where’s MY choice It is estimated by a charity that , children have long CovidImage: Getty Images iStockphotoopinionByPolly Hudson:,  Dec | commentsAt first it seemed sensible. Then insulting. Now  Scandalously negligent. Primary school age children in this country currently have the highest infection rates they’ve ever had during the pandemic - but there are no plans to start vaccinating them. Nearly five million - year olds have been jabbed in America, on Sunday the scheme was approved in Australia, and the rollout is expected to start next week in some European countries after it was given the green light by the European Medicines Agency. But here, nothing.Some parents won’t want their kids to be vaccinated of course, and that’s their choice - but I do, desperately. So where’s MY choice I’d take my seven-year-old to a back street illegal vaccinatorsuch a thing existed, but unfortunately it doesn’t.Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section Omicron is only just getting started, and already a whopping , kids tested positive for covid last week, with actual infection levels estimated to be up to four times higher than that. Charity Long Covid Kids reports that , children currently have long covid - , of whom have been suffering with it for over a year.Respected epidemiologist and public health researcher Deepti Gurdasani puts it simply, “Infection of children with SARS-Cov- will be one of those actions we look back at in history and wonder how on earth it was allowed to happen - by those who should’ve been protecting them.” I’ve gratefully accepted every vaccine my son has been offered, starting when he was eight weeks old. I’m lucky to live in a country where they’re available as standard, for free. And I believe it’s my duty to ensure he’s up to date with them, in accordance with the No part of parenting: trying to keep your kid safe. Also of course in this case, where coronavirus is still circulating, jabbing everyone means the whole community is protected. It’s better for everyone. The news about Omicron is becoming ever more concerning, and there were already upwards of , Covid cases a day before it reared its unwelcome head. And yet, every morning, I deliver my son into an environment where he mixes freely with hundreds of others, with no mitigations. No masks, no bubbles, no ventilation. And no vaccine either. Best of British luck, eh, kid  Vaccinating children was approved in the US at the end of October. Prof Jon Levy, chairman of the Department of Environmental Health at Boston University, welcomed the news: “Every paediatrician I know is eager to get their own kids age - vaccinated immediately. “They plan to get as many kids vaccinated in their offices as quickly as possible. If that doesn’t tell you how safe and effective the vaccine is. I don’t know what will.” If the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation know something we don’t – and have good reason why they’re dragging their feet on protecting the smallest, most helpless people in our communities – they need to speak up. Otherwise, they’re forcing us to fail our children. title: top foreign office civil servant
story: Top Foreign Office civil servant slammed for staying on holiday almost  weeks after Kabul fellPermanent secretary Sir Philip Barton remained on his break even after former Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab jetted back from CreteThe Foreign Offices top civil servant, Sir Philip Barton, giving evidence on the evacuation from Afghanistan Image: PAByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec | commentsThe Foreign Officeaposs top civil servant faced a barrage of criticism after admitting he stayed on his summer holiday for almost two weeks after Afghanistan fell to to the Taliban.Permanent secretary Sir Philip Barton was blasted for being away in the UK and abroad as the Taliban overran the war-torn nation in August. He revealed that he was on leave from August  and did notuntil August , some  days after the Afghan government collapsed.He told the Commons Foreign Affairs Committee: “If I had my time again I would have come back from my leave earlier than I did.” Sir Philip was criticised by MPs for failing to come back from holidays to deal with the crisis.He even chose to remain on holiday after then-Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab jetted home from a luxury break in Crete.Conservative MP Alicia Kearns told Sir Philip: I donapost think it is enough to say, aposmea culpaapos. How in two weeks did at no point, you go, aposI canapost, I have to go in and protect my people’ ”  The civil servant said cover arrangements were in place and he stayed in touch with the department all the way through the period. He also defended ordering crisis centre workers to stick to eight-hour shts - despite a “monumental volume” of emails from desperate Afghans and Britons hoping to flee. Tory MP Bob Seely said: “People clocking off after eight hours, not bothering to come in at weekends - it’s all complacent and wooly and waffly and unfocused and sort of just a bit rubbish.” But Sir Philip hit back: “There isn’t a clocking off culture at all … when we’re in a full blown crisis it’s very intense. “We have an eight-hour sht system and we make sure therefore that people are getting a period of rest and then coming back onto shts.” MPs also heard explosive claims from Raphael Marshall, who worked for the Foreign Office during Operation Pitting and who branded the ministry’s response to the Afghan crisis dysal and chaotic. Allied forces withdrew as Taliban fighters advanced - sparking a refugee emergency as worried Afghans tried to flee Mr Marshall claimed just % of Afghan nationals who applied to leave under one UK scheme received help. Some were murdered after being left in Kabul after the Taliban swept to power, he alleged in written evidence to the committee. Meanwhile, a row broke out over claims the PM intervened to order the rescue of animals from Afghanistan after the Taliban takeover. Sir Philip insisted there was was no prioritisation of animals in the evacuation from Kabul, after a whistleblower claimed Boris Johnson issued an instruction to save animals from the Nowzad shelter during the evacuation effort.Whistleblower Mr Marshall accused Mr Johnson of issuing an instruction to save animals from the Nowzad shelter - potentially putting British troopsapos lives at risk and preventing people from fleeing Kabul. He told MPs there was an instruction from the Prime Minister to use considerable capacity to transport Nowzadaposs animals. Mr Johnson branded the claim complete nonsense and Downing Street said it was entirely untrue. Former Royal Marine Paul Pen Farthing, who ran the shelter, launched a high-profile campaign to get his staff and animals out, using a plane funded through donations. The Government sponsored clearance for the charter flight - triggering allegations animals had been prioritised over people. It has previously been claimed the PM’s we Carrie also intervened to ensure the animals were transported to the UK. But Mr Johnson’s spokesman said neither the Prime Minister nor Mrs Johnson were involved. Yet campaigner Dominic Dyer insisted he had called on the Johnsons for help.I forced the Prime Ministeraposs arm, I think all of us behind this campaign did,” he told the BBC. The next day, the senior commander in the Ministry of Defence, in the Air Force department, contacted me and said you can have your flight authorisation and we could get that plane down on the ground into Afghanistan.“Thataposs my proof because without the intervention from the Prime Minister,would have continued to block the operation. Labour leader Keir Starmer said of Mr Marshall’s evidence: “This is a devastating testimony that lays bare the shambolic incompetence of the Government in protecting thousands of Afghans to whom we owed a duty.”Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Boris JohnsonBen WallaceLabour PartyConservative PartyTalibanForeign OfficeAir ForceBBCMinistry of DefenceCivil servantsPublic servicesPoliticsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: trophy hunting imports law unlikely
story: Exclusive: Trophy hunting imports law unlikely to appear in Parliament before springThe Government is set to resist demands to support a backbenchers bid to legislate using a Private Members Bill on Friday - and campaigners are angry at fresh delaysThe Mirror understands the Governments legislation will not appear before the spring at the earliest Image: ShutterstockByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  Dec | commentsLaws to ban trophy hunting imports are unlikely to be brought forward until the spring at the earliest, we can reveal. The Government is not expected to back Labour MP John Spellar’s bid to introduce legislation when his Private Member’s Bill s to the Commons on Friday. During a recent meeting with Environment Minister Lord Zac Goldsmith, a leading campaigner was told the department “hoped” the Government’s own Bill would be brought to Parliament “next spring or summer” - but there was no guarantee. The Tories pledged at the  election to ban hunters importing their spoils - including wild animals’ bodies, heads, skins and tusks - to Britain, but campaigners are frustrated at delays.  On Thursday, the All-Party Parliamentary Group on Trophy Hunting will unveil a billboard poster outside Parliament to highlight the campaign to stop hunters bringing their sick souvenirs to the UK. The billboard will tour the country to raise awareness and urge people to contact their MPs to put more pressure on the government. However, supporters of a ban are hopeful the Government’s proposal will cover “virtually all animals” with “no exemptions or loopholes” and potential prison sentences for offenders. Outlawing the importation of hunting trophies would mark a victory for the Mirror, which has led the fight.  Campaign to Ban Trophy Hunting founder Eduardo Goncalves said: “We’ve yet to see the details, but all the signs so far point to this being a very good Bill. “It appears that the scope includes virtually all species, offenders could face jail, and perhaps best of all it seems exemptions have been ruled out. “This could indeed be an historic moment. “Hats off to the Government for listening to voters, and to the Mirror and its readers who have kept up the pressure in order to make this ban a reality.” But he added: “The question that still remains is when is the Government going to bring this Bill to Parliament   “Ideally the Government should announce that at the same time as publishing the outline of the Bill. “If it can’t do this, then it should seriously consider adopting John Spellar’s Private Member’s Bill. Mr Spellar said: “These Government delays are ridiculous.  “The public and Parliament want to end this vile trade and so - they say - do Boris Johnson and the Conservative Party. “They just need to get a grip and get a move on - or even back my Bill on Friday.” Speaking in the Commons last month, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said: “We are going to introduce legislation this Parliament to ban the import of hunting trophies, and delivering the change that we promised.”Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Conservative PartyJohn SpellarZac GoldsmithPoliticsEnd trophy hunting importsTrophy Hunting" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: autistic boy best birthday ever
story: Autistic boy has best birthday ever due to stunning reaction after kids snubbed partyHarry Brinkworth, who is celebrating his th birthday today, was cheered up by complete strangers after he was told by classmates that they could go to his birthday because their parents didnt like himHarry,  has been receiving hundreds of birthday cards from strangers, with possibly even more in the post Image: SWNSByDouglas WhitbreadShiler Mahmoudi:,  Dec | commentsA boy with autism who was snubbed by his classmates for his party invites has had the aposbest birthday everapos. Harry Brinkworth, who is  today, received hundreds of birthday cards from well-wishers after children in his class turned down his birthday invitations.The youngster was left sobbing after classmates said apostheir parents did not like himapos and would not go to his party.Harryaposs mum Hannah Brinkworth, , decide to take to Instagram to try and cheer up her son after the cruel incident.She asked members of the public to send him a birthday card to make his birthday special. This morning Harry woke up to almost  cards from kind strangers across the world wishing him a great birthday, with possibly even more in the post.  Mum Hannah is also organising him a bowling birthday party after she was approach by other parents saying their children wanted to celebrate his th birthday with him. When asked what he thought of the hundreds of cards and messages that he had received, Harry said: It was the best birthday I have ever had. Hannah was initially upset by the way he was treated but has since been blown away by the response of complete strangers. She wanted to raise awareness of autism and to give her son something to make his birthday. Weaposre not doing it for any kind of pity party, and we donapost want people to buy or send expensive things, she added. Itaposs just a case of making people aware of it and making a little boyaposs day.Harry has been receiving the cards since December  when Hannah posted on Instagram with some coming from people as far away as New Zealand. He was so excited to read all the nice messages.Hannah said: It was special for him, and he enjoyed it - he just wanted to read every single one of them like a book.Everybody was referring to him as a superhero and saying that heaposd done such a positive thing.He had a card from Dubai and a card from Texas, and also one from somebody in Canada and New Zealand.All of the excitement made Harry very happy, but he also has understood the importance to be inclusive and kind towards others.Hannah said: He understands the bigger picture of it, and he knows why itaposs important and itaposs not just him.After today, the conversation will continue and so it should - thataposs the important part.With autism, people are almost scared to have the conversation and scared to bring it up, but we shouldnapost be - we should celebrate our kids regardless.Thereaposs been so many people reaching out and sharing similar experiences.Every birthday, Hannah tries to organise a birthday for Harry but none of the children every come.  She said that it is usually the parents and not the children who do not want to go, and that there needs to be a change in attitude in how parents talk about children who may have additional or special education needs.Hannah continued: Harry is autistic, and weaposve known for a long time, and heaposs not a bad kid in any way.He always wants birthday parties, but historically, every year we try to sort one and nobody comes.I mentioned to him that I needed to know what friends he wanted to come to his party so I could send invites.He said two names, but when I asked again he said they werenapost allowed to come.I said I didnapost understand, and he turned around and, at -years-old, said one had told him their mum doesnapost like him and they canapost play with him.She said: I found it absolutely baffling - itaposs not the kidsapos issue, itaposs the parentsapos lack of understanding about Harryaposs issues.Itaposs not discussed enough how parents talk about kids with additional needs or SEN issues, and they donapost understand the impact of what they say in front of their kids, which is then repeated - itaposs unacceptable.She added: The amount of people who have kids with autism or ADHD who have said similar things, it shows that itaposs not kids who are the issues, itaposs the grown-ups. title: bear grylls moving words fitness
story: Exclusive: Bear Grylls moving words for fitness fanatic teen who survived brain tumour aged A call from Bear Grylls was the icing on the cake for -year-old Darshan McGregor whose wish for gym kit was granted by charity Make-A-Wish UK, backed by the Mirror Christmas AppealWeight to go Darshan McGregor! Image: CollectByNaimah Archibald-PowellJunior Feature Writer:,  Dec | commentsGetting a delivery of weights and home gym equipment was a dream come true for teen fitness fanatic Darshan McGregor. And after coming through gruelling treatment for a brain tumour, a call from Bear Grylls was the icing on the cake for the -year-old. Darshan said: “He’s been through so many le-threatening challenges so he could relate to me. Bear just said keep going, keep fighting and never give up.”Darshan’s wish for gym kit was granted by charity Make-A-Wish UK, backed by the Mirror Christmas Appeal. He says: “It’s been amazing what they’ve been able to do. “It’s really made me happy and it’s one of the things that got me through my treatments, it was one thing I thought about – ‘ I get through this, I’ll get my wish’.” It was just over four-and-a-half years ago that the youngster from Berkhamsted, Herts, was told he had a brain tumour, at the age of nine.  Darshan says: “I feel like I lost part of my childhood – I couldn’t have fun because I was constantly in hospital. It was impossible to be happy.” Mum Samreen, , said: “Because the tumour was in the thalamus, right in the middle of the brain, taking a biopsy or doing any intervention to try to release the fluid in his brain was very high risk. The process was awful.” By Jason Beattie For the majority of families this Christmas will be a joyous time of presents, food and fun. But for some children the festive season will be very dferent. Across the country there are more than , young people who are critically ill. Many will be spending what should be a special time of the year in hospital. Others will have to have treatment, scans or blood tests. With your help we can give them a Christmas that they will always remember. This year’s Mirror Christmas Appeal is raising funds for Make-A-Wish UK that helps seriously ill young people make their dreams come true.It could be they want to meet their hero or heroine or feed an animal at the zoo or travel to see Santa in Lapland. The money raised could help Joshua, six, who has severe epilepsy, achieve his wish of a bedroom makeover or Summer, also six, who has acute leukaemia and dreams of a bouncy castle. Each year Make-A-Wish helps hundreds of critically ill children achieve their letime’s ambition. But to make a wish come true takes an army of volunteers, supporters and donors. That’s why every penny you donate could make a dference. Granting a wish can transform a child’s le. It gives them something to look forward to. For others it provides a special memory which makes the treatment they need more bearable.It can also help their parents who, despite doing everything they can for their sick child, feel it is not enough. Jason Suckley, Make-A-Wish UK chief executive, said: “I met the family of a boy who was recovering from brain surgery. “His grandmother told me how dficult it had been for her to watch her daughter struggle with the challenges of her son’s condition.But while they were enjoying his wish together, her daughter turned to her and said, ‘There is still magic in this world isn’t there mum ’ . “That’s just one instance that illustrates how the power of a wish lies in sharing positive memories with loved ones. “Every donation from Mirror readers will help us create those memories – bringing joy to ill children and their families during the darkest of times.” Samreen and marketing exec dad Fraser, , consulted experts and decided proton beam therapy in the US was the way to go – but it cost more than £,. A plea for government funding was turned down, so they raised it themselves by remortgaging their home and setting up a Go Fund Me page. After chemotherapy in the UK they went to Boston for the beam therapy and radiotherapy, and by October  Darshan was cancer-free. If you’d like to give £ but do not want marketing communications, text LIGHT NO to .You can text more than onceyou wish to donate more. Post: Please post cheques payable to MAKE-A-WISH UK to Freepost address below: Freepost Plus RUCS-LHTL-CJGU Make-A-Wish Mirror Appeal Make-A-Wish UK, Seventh Floor, Thames Tower, Station Road, Reading, Berkshire RG LX During treatment his interest in fitness and nutrition took off. To help others he made videos for his Kidlivz YouTube channel showing him making healthy recipes. Darshan will celebrate five years cancer-free next year. story: Wes heartbreaking tribute to husband stabbed to death in road rage attackJames Stokoe, , was murdered in front of his four-year-old son, Harry, when he was stabbed to death by a complete strangerJames Stokoe with his son Harry who was four when he witnessed his dads murder Image: PAByJeremy ArmstrongNews Reporter:,  Dec Updated:,  Dec A heartbroken we has paid tribute to her husband who was killed in a road rage attack, saying he will be aposloved as long as I breatheapos. James Stokoe, , was murdered in front of his four-year-old son, Harry, when he was stabbed to death by a complete stranger. Alexander Layton, , was jailed for le with a minimum -year term as Jamesapos family spoke of their aposunimaginableapos loss. The two men had a row when Mr Stokoe had to brake suddenly as Layton crossed Trenchard Avenue in Thornaby, Teesside on May  last year. Layton was captured on CCTV and Dashcam by passing motorists when he plunged the in kitchen kne six times into Mr Stokoe as Harry sat in a car seat in the back of the BMW.  Peter Makepeace QC, prosecuting, told Teesside crown court there were several aggravating factors in the case, including the impact of the crime on Harry at such a young age. The offence was committed in the presence of the victimaposs four-year-old son, he said. In the victim impact statement of his mother Alex Stokoe, she told of her sonaposs inability to stay in the car as it drives down Trenchard Avenue because he had so many memories of the traumatic events.  Harry is also fearfulanyone approaches an open window of a car, the court heard. Heartbroken mum Alex, a university lab technician, watched proceedings via a video link as she felt unable to attend in person, Mr Makepeace said. Instead, he read out her moving victim impact statement. She wrote: James will be remembered and loved as long as I breathe. Our son will always know what a wonderful father James was and how much he loved him.  She told how she was a single mother at , not because she chose to be, but because her husband had been apostorn away from usapos. She said: I will never be able to accept referring to James in the past tense. He should be here. Explaining to her son that his dad aposwould not be coming home againapos was the most painful moment of her le, she added. She said: A child should not be frightened when the car window is open in case someone comes to hurt them.  I now face le as a -year-old widow. I have lost not just my husband but my best friend and soulmate, he was everything to me. To tell your four-year-old that his daddy is dead and wonapost be coming home is truly the most horrendous, painful moment of my le. To know your child has seen things that no child should ever have to see or hear. To explain the process of death and how James died. Funeral, cremation the finality of it all, so our son could understand what was happening around him. Harry accepts as much as a child of that age can, that his daddy is dead, that he isnapost coming back. She told Layton: Harry has needed therapy because of the trauma that you have caused. In a heart-rending testimony, Jamesapos mother Doreen told how she had lost her only child. Her world had been changed forever on the day she lost her aposamazingapos son, who loved his family with all his heart, aposhis hopes and dreams for the future never to be realisedapos. Sentencing Layton to le imprisonment, His Honour Judge Howard Crowson said he had inflicted eight serious injuries to his victim as he sat in the front seat of his car, unable to defend himself. James Stokoe was a happy, successful husband, father and son, he added. His four-year-old son was in the rear of the car...and is still in fear of another attack. Layton had a history of violence, including attacks on his own mother.Temporary Det Supt Helen Barker of Cleveland Police said after the case: This was a shocking incident which occurred in the presence of Jamesapos young son, which will undoubtedly have had a huge effect on him.The death of James has had a traumatic impact on his whole family. James was a much loved dad to his little boy and was married in the Dominican Republic. The popular graduate of Teesside University was a keen footballer, a motorbike enthusiast and worked in the motor industry. At the time of his death, friends paid tribute to a gentle giant who was affectionately known as Big Red. story: Boy, , may have only months to live with race on to find bone marrow transplantOlcan Wilkes has developed aplastic anaemia and his parents Sam and Genevieve of Newent, Gloucester, are urging everyone to register as a donor to give him a chance of having a le-saving bone marrow opOlcan, seven, with four-year-old Hunter Image: ©Matt MackeyByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Dec | commentsA little boy is in desperate need of a lesaving bone marrow ­transplant after being diagnosed with a rare blood disorder. Olcan Wilkes, seven, may have months to live after developing aplastic anaemia, and no current donor match available for his bone tissue type. His parents Sam and Genevieve, both , of Newent, Glos, are urging everyone to register as a donor and give their boy and others a chance. On average, % of patients with the ­condition die within a year unless a transplant is undertaken. Dad Sam said: “We need to find a bone marrow match, that’s the only cure.” Olcan is having two or three platelet transfusions a week and a blood transfusion every fortnight to keep him alive. But any small infection could hit his weakened immunity hard. Sam said: “If you aren’t on top of it, it could be ­catastrophic. The doctors have to treat everything asit’s worst-case scenario.” Olcan’s energy levels are often very low, but his parents try their best to get him outside with brother, Hunter, four.  “We take him out to the beach or wherever, places where other people aren’t around,” Sam, a farmer, said. In July, Genevieve was offered a job in Belfast and moved with her sons to Antrim, meaning Sam splits his time. It was soon after moving they noticed bruising on Olcan’s ankles. Then during a walk, he fell and his knees ­immediately turned “absolutely black and blue”. Tests in September showed he had the rare condition. Sam said he and Genevieve are amazed at how quickly he has adapted to hospital trips.  “He’s very intelligent,” Sam said. “We say you need a transplant because your blood cells need a kick up the bum.” Olcan is having immunosuppressive therapy called anti-thymocyte globulin, which could make him dependent of gruelling transfusions, and prolong his le until a donor is found. The severity of his condition means the chances of ATG working are fairly low. Sam said: “Within nine months most patients get an infection and die.”  He added as a family they are trying to raise awareness about becoming a donor. “The fact it could just happen to anyone is very upsetting,” he said.Register to be a bone marrow donor at: www.dkms.org.uk register-now Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TherapyOrgan donationParenting" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Britain sends more than  asylum seekers back home - after taking them in as kidsThe asylum seekers arrived in Britain as lone children and were given temporary leave to remain, but sent back to Afghanistan and Iraq after their th birthdaysMigrants crossing the Channel earlier this year Image: Getty ImagesByGeraldine McKelvieInvestigations EditorMaeve McClenaghan:,  Dec Britain has sent more than  asylum seekers back to Afghanistan and Iraq over the last five years after taking them in as unaccompanied children. All were given temporary leave to remain in the UK but were ed to their country of origin after turning . The data was obtained by The Bureau of Investigative Journalism and relates to removals over the last five years. A report by the charity Refugee Support Network - now rebranded as Refugee Education UK - suggests some of those ing face perilous situations. Its researchers interviewed a range of Afghan ees for its After Return report, some of whom said they’d been caught in bombs or suicide attacks.  One, named only as Mohammed, told the charity in  that he’d been forced to join the Taliban for his own protection. He claimed he was “tortured” before leaving for the UK as a child and needed protection from his “enemies”. Then , he said: “I thought a lot about my decision, but I did not see any other way. I had to join the Taliban to be able to defend myself from my enemies and survive.” Others reported struggling with mental health issues, and accessing work and education. Under current laws, unaccompanied children arriving in the UK are expected to make asylum claims in the same way as adults - outlining exactly why ing to their home country would present a risk for them. Those rejected are granted leave to remain in the UK until six months before their th birthday.  Once this expires, children have the right to apply for an extension, but experts say very few of these applications are successful. Ben Davison, head of immigration at Ison Harrison Solicitors, said: If their appeal is unsuccessful, thataposs the point where the Home Office can take removal action. Appeals are more likely to be unsuccessful becauseitaposs going to be recognised that they will be at risk, itaposs usually recognised first time around. They can argue that they have established a private le in the UK, but there are specic rules. “Children generally need to have been in the UK for seven years to show it would be unduly harsh to remove them and those who have been here for a shorter period donapost meet that set criteria. Many are left in limbo as they wait for their claims to be processed - often housed in poorly maintained asylum accommodation. Mr Davison says that, even in light of the Taliban takeover, there is no guarantee those who arrived as unaccompanied children will be allowed to stay. He added: Itaposs not enough to simply say, aposAfghanistan has been taken overapos. It will be upon the applicant - child or adult - to make a case for why they particularly are at risk.  Our data relates to at least  asylum seekers removed from the UK between  and . It comes amid a spike in desperate asylum seekers paying traffickers to get them to the UK due to the lack of safe routes. Last month,  people drowned in the Channel while trying to reach Britain on a dinghy. A Home Office spokesman said: “Those with no right to be in the UK and foreign national offenders should be in no doubt that we will do whatever is necessary to remove them. “This is what the public rightly expects and why we regularly operate flights to dferent countries.” A foreign national offender is anyone remanded or convicted on criminal charges who does not have an absolute legal right to remain in this country. But when asked by the Mirror, the Home Office was unable to say how many,any, of the  people in question had been convicted of crimes. The spokesman added: “In light of the developing situation, we suspended s to Afghanistan in July and we do not carry out enforced s to Syria for the same reason. “We keep s under review and make assessments based on the latest country information.” Read MoreRead MoreMost ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON TalibanHome OfficeMental healthIraq" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
